title.narrative: WATER:WATER,SANITATION AND HYGIENE

description.narrative: By 2023, increased proportions of population have access to adequate, equitable and sustainable basic drinking water services in households, schools and health care facilities in target rural, peri-urban and humanitarian settings, which contributes to Climate Change, Disaster Risks And Envionmental Degradation, Climate Change, Disaster Risks And Envionmental Degradation (Covid), Reducing Child Poverty, Safe And Equitable Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Services And Practices, Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Systems And Empowerment Of Communities, Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Systems And Empowerment Of Communities (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Community Engagement, Social And Behaviour Change, Evaluations, Research And Data, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2023, increased proportions of the population use adequate, equitable and sustainable basic drinking water, sanitation and hygiene services in households, schools and healthcare facilities in target rural, peri-urban and humanitarian settings.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2023, increased proportions of population have access to adequate, equitable and sustainable basic drinking water services inhouseholds, schools and health care facilities in target rural, peri-urban and humanitarian settings

description.narrative: In 2021, UNICEF played a significant role in expanding access to safe drinking water. Access to water in the humanitarian response, UNICEF supported 248,529 persons (126,749 women and 121,780 men). This includes 107 398 persons who gained access to a sustainable drinking water service through;durable solutions. In addition, because of UNICEF direct support, 398 schools benefited from newly constructed and rehabilitated water supply facilities. Thanks to UNICEF &39;support to the Ministry of Hydraulics, Energy and Mines, there was ongoing water quality analysis to ensure that water supplied is free from contamination for 79 wells across Burundi. | Status:Constrained | As-of Date:23/12/2021
